            your healthy internal parent or internal voice, as frequently as possible.

action_step:
I have been focusing this week on positive intentions and noticing daily “choice points\" where you can
            invoke your intention to take yourself in a positive direction. Today, when you notice a choice point, when
            you are engaged in thinking about something in your life, call on your healthy internal parent to give you
            advice and direction. This is the part of you we have been developing, coming from a place of love,
            compassion, acceptance, support and self-care.
journal_entry: Write about your efforts to develop a healthy internal voice.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Give yourself credit for calling on your healthy internal parent. Find your way to
            The Path.
quote:
“Neurons that fire together, wire together\" D.O. Hebb“ 
 Affirmations direct the right neurons to fire together\" Stephen Sideroff, PhD

step_of_the_day.title: Creating 3 affirmations that focus on your intentions and support new nerve growth (Pillars #1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
Although today’s step is about affirmations, remember to take time to practice a relaxation exercise to best
            cope with stress. Also, remember to honor and give attention to the important relationships in your life.

action_step:
Create 3 affirmations to support the intentions you have been working on this week. These statements are
            written “as if\" what you are wanting – your goals – have already been achieved. For example, if you are
            wanting to shift into more positive approaches to life, an affirmation might be “When I look into the
            future, I immediately think of how everything will work out well\".
journal_entry: In your journal write your affirmations and any difficulties you have with them.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How well did you follow the steps last week to strengthen your intentions and change
            your brain? Give yourself credit for your successes while holding yourself accountable to improve – where
            you fell short. Remember why you are striving to be on The Path!
quote: “Find what’s really important in life\" Buddha

step_of_the_day.title: Finding your “North star\", what’s truly important (Pillars # 1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
Life is so complex. I have clients who have literally hundreds of items on their “to do\" list! Yet, how
            many of these – or the items on your list – can be labeled as “most important\"? Do you waste time on less
            significant actions while ignoring what will make the greatest difference in your life?I like to break down most important into three areas: personal, relationship and career or livelihood.
            Personal is guided by your healthy internal parent and involves physical, emotional, mental and spiritual
            health. Relationship is how you stay connected, support, love and care for family and friends and receive
            their love and kindness. And career/livelihood is how you take care of and grow “business\" however you
            define that.

action_step:
Start your week by identifying what’s most important in these three areas of your life. Make sure you
            prioritize steps, this week, to support what’s most important.
journal_entry: Write about what’s most important to you.

review_and_appreciate: Review and Appreciate: Are you focused this week on important actions? Put yourself on The Path.
quote:
"If you look at what you have in life, you'll always have more. If you look at what you don't have in life,
            you'll never have enough." -Oprah Winfrey

step_of_the_day.title: Stepping back and appreciating what you have. Finding satisfaction in your life (Pillars #1, 5 & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
A primary objective of life is to notice what’s out of balance – physically, emotionally, mentally and
            spiritually - and taking the necessary actions to restore balance and harmony. A key aspect of resilience
            and success is being aware that this process is always going on. It might be a need that just arises in the
            moment, or unfinished emotional business from many years ago. The problem we address is that because we
            ignore our feelings, many of our needs or unfinished business are unconscious and thus go unmet. Most of the
            steps of this program help you identify your needs and then take the appropriate actions to meet and resolve
            these needs. Otherwise we find ourselves going in the wrong direction.But this program is also about noticing needs that are being met and appreciating the harmony you do have.
            This is part of the rhythm of life: interspersing the hard work to get your needs met – with periods in
            which you appreciate your efforts and feel a sense of satisfaction about what you have and what you have
            achieved in life.

action_step:
Take some time today to look at what you have. It can be personally in terms of your health or growth. It
            can be in the relationships you have or have established. And it can be what you have achieved in life.
            Accept these blessings and allow yourself to feel a sense of satisfaction, love and accomplishment.
journal_entry: Write about what you feel good about in your life.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How did it feel to appreciate what you have? Appreciation and gratitude put you on
            The Path.
quote: "Life is what happens when you're busy making other plans." -John Lennon

step_of_the_day.title: Being present takes intention and practice. Let’s make an effort to be present today (Pillar #7)
step_of_the_day.content:
You don’t realize how difficult it is to be present, until you try. Simply counting your breaths – count
            them up to four and then start over at one – turns out to be an eye-opener. Try it. How quickly does your
            mind wander to a thought? Usually after just a few seconds, you’ve lost track of your count. There are many
            reasons for this difficulty ranging from the media switching images and sound every few seconds to keep you
            hooked, to your own tendency to avoid and get distracted due to learned fear and an accumulation of
            unfinished business that your brain is constantly trying to address.Being present makes you more capable to succeed as well as more able to experience positive feelings. To get
            good at it, requires practice.

action_step:
Schedule a few times during the day to practice being present. At these appointed times, engage in the
            following 10-minute mindfulness exercise: sit quietly and breath at 6 breaths per minute: four seconds in
            and six seconds out. Find something to focus on. It can be your breath or an object in your environment. If
            you lose “presence\" or focus during the exercise, simply notice where you shifted to – without judgment –
            and return to being present.
journal_entry: Write about any resistance you have to doing this exercise.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How much effort did you engage in yesterday to practice “presence\"? If you followed
            through, congratulations and congratulate yourself. If you didn’t, ask yourself how much you are willing to
            commit to be resilient and successful. See you on The Path.
quote: "When you reach the end of your rope, tie a knot in it and hang on." -Franklin D. Roosevelt

step_of_the_day.title:
Pushing through to reach higher levels. Most are not born with determination; you develop it through hard
            work (Pillars #1 & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
I see two important take-aways from what our 32nd president said in this statement. The first is that when
            you are on your last breath, you find your second breath. The other is a sense of determination. A
            determination to push through, to reach inside for untapped strength and resilience. I’d like to focus on
            this latter concept as it implies a methodology for developing strength.

action_step:
Where in your life would additional determination make a difference? Like the weightlifter who, when he or
            she can’t do another rep, finds the inner strength to do one or two more. It is in that extra effort that
            change occurs. Where can you engage in an extra effort? Where have you stopped short? Take some action today
            where you push yourself, and then appreciate your effort.
journal_entry: Write about your history of determination: where you have done so, and where you have not.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: If you took a difficult step yesterday to push through, take a moment to appreciate
            strengthening your “will\" and determination. If you didn’t, you can still do it today. Be on The Path
quote: “Experience is biology\"“Where attention goes, neuron firing flows and neural connections grow\" Daniel Siegel

step_of_the_day.title:
Where does your attention go? Does it serve you? Making sure you focus your attention in the right direction
            (Pillars 1, 5, 7, & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
Many of you are familiar with my talks over the years, on the mind-body connection. My research and programs
            are based on how experience is intimately connected with physical symptoms as well as resilience and
            personal success. We are learning in greater and greater detail exactly what the mechanisms are that
            translate experience into our biology, into actual changes in brain and body.We now know that what we focus on – mentally – shapes the development of neurons and neuronal circuits. And
            then, these circuits represent our thinking, attitude and other aspects of behavior.

action_step:
In order to reinforce and develop brain circuits that support healthy resilience and success today, make it
            your intention to see the positive in each of your experiences. If you notice that you have critical or
            negative thoughts, switch to a more positive outlook and perspective.
journal_entry: Write about how you imagine your own brain circuits are wired.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you pay attention to where you placed your attention yesterday? Did you make an
            effort to choose to focus in a positive direction – to guide positive brain connections? Be on The Path
quote:
“Experiences and memories are subjective, and influenced by your Primitive Gestalt Patterns\" Stephen
            Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title:
How negativity, anxiety and worry are perpetuated. Using awareness to focus and change your experiences and
            your memories (Pillars 5 & 6)
step_of_the_day.content:
Yesterday I talked about how your “choice\" of focus determines the actual structure of your brain and its
            neuronal connections. I put choice in quotation marks because most of the time we don’t recognize we have a
            choice, but instead focus the way we have always focused. Today I want to show you how your abdication of
            this power; of your agency, or your choice, leads to big problems. Here is a typical example with its
            inevitable consequences:You become anxious and fearful of some future event. You worry about what can go wrong. It might even keep
            you up at night worrying and trying to control the outcome. Then the event happens, and your worst fears do
            not occur. The result is usually much more positive – perhaps even the most positive outcome. Here are the
            results of this experience:1. Despite your success, the memory of this experience is less about the success or relief. Instead what
            gets remembered is the anxiety, the stress, the worry, and the upset that led up to the event. (After all,
            much more time, energy and emotion went into the time prior to the event.) It becomes another negatively
            stored memory – instead of the success that should be fully remembered.2. The relief or success of this experience is now paired with all the worry, stress and anxiety that lead
            up to it. Thus, anxiety, worry and stress become paired with success: Neurons that fire together wire
            together (D.O. Hebb)!!!3. If we are always pairing anxiety and stress with success, we will continue bringing on anxiety and
            stress.

action_step:
Pay attention to how this pattern plays out. Make an effort to shift your focus, to start paying attention
            and remembering when things work out for you.
journal_entry: How are you attached to your anxiety, fear, and stress? Write about it. What can you do differently?

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How well did you follow the steps last week to strengthen your intentions and change
            your brain? Give yourself credit for your successes while holding yourself accountable to improve – where
            you fell short. Remember why you are striving to be on The Path!
quote: “Resilient communities, like the tide, raise all ships\" Stephen Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title: Contributing to a resilient community. Finding purpose beyond yourself (Pillar #3)
step_of_the_day.content:
Resilient communities support our core needs of safety and connection. When these needs are met, we do
            better and thrive. Many factors contribute to these feelings. Recent events – the pandemic, the resulting
            economic crisis, west coast fires, recurring hurricanes, and “Black lives matter\" - have highlighted the
            real and existential dangers we as a community are experiencing that create a baseline of uncertainty and
            danger that challenge any sense of safety. Messages that pit different groups against each other create an
            atmosphere of hostility rather than connection and love.For the first time in its 175-year history, Scientific American has made an endorsement for President. They
            say, “We do not do this lightly, the evidence and the science show that Donald Trump has badly damaged the
            U.S. and its people – because he rejects evidence and science.\" They go on to say that his “Dishonest and
            inept\" response to the COVID-19 pandemic, his attacks on medical care, government scientists, environmental
            protections and public health research have severely weakened the nation’s ability to respond to the
            greatest challenges of our time, most notably COVID-19 and climate change. And they note, ““In his ongoing
            denial of reality, Trump has hobbled U.S. preparations for climate change, falsely claiming that it does not
            exist and pulling out of international agreements to mitigate it,\" the editors write. “The changing climate
            is already causing a rise in heat-related deaths and an increase in severe storms, wildfires and extreme
            flooding.\"Like Scientific American, I typically stay neutral when it comes to politics. My intentions and mission are
            to help you heal, find your healthy center and values. From that place, I’m sure you will make resilient and
            successful choices. But with my pillar #3: “relationship with something greater\" I must address your
            relationship with the larger community and humanity. As I note above, a resilient community will contribute
            to your own resilience by helping you feel safe and connected.

action_step:
Make your own choice as to what you can do, where you can place your energies, to support your community
            becoming more resilient. Whether it’s politically, by giving blood, donating time to an important cause, or
            any other way. “What goes around, comes around\" is a statement of what happens when you send your energy
            out into the world. I like to say that we are in partnership with the Universe. Whatever the energy we send
            out, the Universe makes a matching donation.
journal_entry: Write about your personal belief system and what you do to support the world around you.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: What energy did you send out into your environment yesterday? What step did you take
            to make a difference? Stay on The Path!
quote: “If it’s the best path, you take it; without thinking how difficult it is\" Stephen Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title:
Choosing the best path means not listening to any internal negativity. Establishing/strengthening a pattern
            of constructive positivism (Pillars #1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, &9)
step_of_the_day.content:
How many times do you say, as you face your options, “that’s difficult\" or “I don’t know if I can do it\",
            or even, “that’s impossible\"? Do you automatically go into what can get in your way, what can go wrong, or
            worry about the judgments of others or not succeeding?Every choice has positive and negative aspects and uncertainty. When you choose your path, you are choosing
            that path with the greatest likelihood of success, with the greatest ratio of positive to negative aspects.
            There will always be a negative with any choice. An Olympic athlete once said, when asked if she thought
            about crashing in her slalom competition, “if I did, I don’t think I’d ever compete. I certainly wouldn’t
            win.\"

action_step:
Notice how you evaluate your choices and how you make your decisions. When you make a decision, focus on why
            it’s the right choice, and why you will succeed.
journal_entry: Write about how positive you are in your expectations.

review_and_appreciate: Review and Appreciate: Did you have a positive focus to your thinking yesterday? That put you on The Path!
quote:
"Your time is limited, so don't waste it living someone else's life. Don't be trapped by dogma – which is
            living with the results of other people's thinking." - Steve Jobs

step_of_the_day.title:
Strengthening your ability to be present. Being present to support your independence and self-direction
            (Pillar #7)
step_of_the_day.content:
Presence, my seventh pillar of resilience and success, is about an awareness of the moment. If you are going
            to be “response – able\" in life, you first must be in the moment to have choice. Whether we use the phrase,
            “monkey brain\", or habitual patterns, or, as Steve Jobs refers to “dogma\", most of the time we are living
            by the rules and conditioning of others. We have the old voice in our heads – “worry about this\", “do it
            this way\", “someone will be upset with you\", “it’s too difficult\", “look at what he or she has\", “you
            are getting behind\", “you should be …\".None of this serves or supports you. It only adds to your stress, dissatisfaction and self-doubt.I have been encouraging you to notice these messages and then to shift into your Healthy Internal Parent
            coming from a place of Love, Compassion, Acceptance, Support and Care. But to do this you need to be present
            – in the moment – to have this awareness to take The Path.

action_step:
Make it your intention to be present in as many moments as possible today. Hold the intention to identify
            old messages in your head and then choose to shift to your healthy internal parent for the healthy and
            correct perspective.
journal_entry: Write about your efforts to notice the old pattern, and to shift into a healthier pattern.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How did you do yesterday with being present? If you made the effort, that has
            already put you on The Path. Did you choose a method for reminding yourself to be present? Did it serve you?
            This helped you walk on The Path.

step_of_the_day.title: Supporting a Resilient environment. Taking action on climate change (Pillar #3)

action_step:
Take responsibility for your role in causing climate warming and for helping to reverse this
            world-threatening crisis. Identify one thing you can change in your behavior to reduce your contribution to
            the problem, such as walking on occasion instead of driving, carpooling more, getting an electric vehicle,
            or installing solar panels on your home. Find ways of educating yourself and others.
journal_entry: Write about your feelings of responsibility surrounding climate change.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How did you do yesterday with being present? If you made the effort, that already
            put you on The Path.
quote: “Stress is in the eye of the beholder\" Stephen Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title: Stress management 101 (Pillar #4)
step_of_the_day.content:
Our number one priority in life is for survival. When we believe we are in danger, our body triggers the
            stress response – the fight or flight response – to protect ourselves. This, obviously, is a good thing. But
            for our purposes today, I want to focus on two aspects of this that are not so good: 1. our response does
            not discriminate between a life-threatening situation, and a friend being angry with you. They both trigger
            the same survival mechanism to danger, and 2. few of our stresses require the fight or flight response, but
            this is what we have inherited to deal with danger. So, when you sit in front of a boss, for example, to
            discuss something uncomfortable, your body mobilizes – muscles tense, heart rate goes up, hormones get
            released for fight or flight - but then you have to hold that energy in. There is no release.This, what I’ve referred to as our “Evolutionary mismatch\", contributes to an already imbalanced stressful
            life, in which we are triggering our stress response too frequently.

action_step:
Your stress response activates your nervous system. You have many stress triggers during the day, but few
            signals of safety that encourage the opposite, the relaxation response. Today, find a few times in which to
            tell yourself, “I’m safe, I can let down my guard\". In addition, find one time today, to practice a
            relaxation exercise, to help your body recover from stress. You can find a free relaxation/visualization
            exercise on my website:www.DrStephenSideroff.com
journal_entry: Write about your experience with stress.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you note times during your day in which you were safe and could let down your
            guard? Did you practice a relaxation exercise to keep your nervous system in balance? Stay on The Path.
quote: “Taking control over your thoughts is the road to stress mastery\" Stephen Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title: Noticing your interpretation of experience to reduce stress (Pillar #5)
step_of_the_day.content:
The way you think determines how much stress you experience. Before you respond in any situation – although
            this process can be instantaneous – you make a determination, an assessment as to whether you are in danger.
            This decision is influenced by your personal history. You can interpret the expression on a friend or
            co-worker’s face, for example, as upset, resulting in a sense of danger and a stress response. Or you might
            simply dismiss it as having nothing to do with you – and your stress response will not be triggered. This is
            a simple example of the continual assessments you make throughout the day.If you focus on what can go wrong, you will engage your stress response – activating your nervous system to
            prepare. If you focus on what can go right – no, or little stress response will be triggered. Of course,
            there are many situations that are stressful to most of us. But by controlling some of your experiences, you
            help master your relationship with stress

action_step:
Notice your experience of stress today. In other words, notice the mobilization of your body, or notice your
            sense of danger, anxiety or worry. In each of these situations identify what you are responding to. What is
            the danger, uncertainty or concern? Try to shift into a more positive perspective and see if this lowers
            your arousal, fear and stress response.
journal_entry: Do you believe that a change in your thinking pattern can lower your experience of stress?

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: What was your experience noticing your stresses? Were you able to alter your
            response by shifting your thinking? That puts you on The Path.
quote:
"Don't judge each day by the harvest you reap but by the seeds that you plant." Robert Louis
            Stevenson

step_of_the_day.title: Resilient living with the Coronavirus Pandemic. Finding “The Path\" through difficulty (Pillars 1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
Pandemic! OK, I said the word. A word that signifies a world-wide catastrophe affecting all areas of our
            lives. For many it has been life-threatening. Some, in fact, have experienced the death of someone close.
            For others, this is always a threat as we experience a myriad of other losses. There is “The Path\" of
            resilience through this experience however, which is now about seven months long. Here are a few “Steps\" on
            The Path:

action_step:
1. Acknowledge the experience and its impact on you.You have been learning that ignoring or pushing feelings down simply leads to anxiety and depression as
            these feelings go underground to affect you unconsciously. Take a few moments to recognize how you are being
            impacted.2. Allow psychological space for your feelings to move through you.Feel and express your feelings – sadness, loss, frustration, anger – and perhaps share them with someone
            close to you. But place a time limit on the expression of these feelings. Before you address feelings, they
            can feel overwhelming and without end. But my experience is that when you allow yourself to feel and express
            them, they become more manageable and tend to dissipate sooner that you might imagine.3. Shift your focus and sow seeds of new growth. There is a rhythm to life. The rhythm of thrusting out into
            the world and then going inside to recuperate and be ready for another foray out. Right now, we are all
            involved in a world-wide rhythm. Many of our outward paths are being blocked. How can you use this time to
            plan, to learn, to develop, to plant seeds? How can you make the best use of this time?
journal_entry: Write about your feelings and then write about how you can use this time most productively.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How well did you follow the steps last week to contribute to a resilient community,
            to be positive, present and master your stress? Give yourself credit for your successes while holding
            yourself accountable to improve – where you fell short. Remember why you are striving to be on The Path!
quote:
"Do not go where the path may lead, go instead where there is no path and leave a trail." -Ralph Waldo
            Emerson

step_of_the_day.title:
The easy path is the old path you are used to taking. The Path may require cutting down and pushing aside
            the thicket that hides it. Find “The\" Path. (Pillar 5)
step_of_the_day.content:
Whatever comes easy, and is familiar to you, may not be your best path. It is the result of a) adaptation to
            a less than optimal childhood environment, and b) unmet and unconscious needs and unfinished business. It is
            important to choose your path based on a healthy approach. I’ve defined this as taking your direction from a
            healthy internal parent coming from a place of love, compassion, acceptance, support and care. Following
            these healthy messages may feel uncomfortable, difficult, or even wrong – but you must push through this
            thicket to be on The Path.

action_step: Today, go to your healthy internal parent for advice on your difficult decisions.
journal_entry: Write about your resistance to following The Path.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you notice any of your choice points? And did you ask the advice of your Healthy
            Internal Parent? You are on The Path.
quote:
"You have brains in your head. You have feet in your shoes. You can steer yourself any direction you
            choose." Dr. Seuss.

step_of_the_day.title: Why choose The Path. How to know when you are on The Path. (Pillars 1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
You have brains in your head, as Dr. Seuss recognizes. If you want to take control of them, you need to
            steer them and your feet onto The Path. I define The Path as living each moment of your life in the most
            optimal way. This optimal way is laid out in my nine pillars of resilience. But since there are many
            ingredients and actions that contribute to this (after all there are 9 pillars to my model of resilience and
            success), you need a framework and methodology so that the process isn’t overwhelming. At any time, if you
            take “a\" step toward your goal, based on my model, that puts you on The Path. Once you are on The Path, you
            can breathe a sigh of relief – without worrying about what’s not getting done.

action_step:
Today’s action step, that puts you on The Path, is to find time to practice a relaxation and visualization
            exercise, such as the complementary one you can download from my website: www.DrStephenSideroff.comThis encourages mastery over your nervous system and your stress response. Try to do this every day:
            practice makes perfect. If you claim you don’t have time – do it however long you have time for – even if
            it’s 5 minutes.
journal_entry: Write about any resistance you have to practicing your relaxation response.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you practice a relaxation exercise yesterday? If you did – congratulations for
            being on The Path. If you didn’t, check in with your commitment to yourself and your health. What’s getting
            in your way? Hope to see you on The Path.
quote: "Never let the fear of striking out keep you from playing the game." Babe Ruth

step_of_the_day.title: To play or not to play. How does fear get in your way? (Pillars #1, 5, & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
One thing that’s great about sports is that it sets up a “field of play\". And the beauty about this is it
            gives you an experience of engagement and lessons to be learned - with very little risk. In life, it’s easy
            to get stuck focusing on the danger, what can go wrong, what mistake you might make or fear of
            rejection.But life can be thought of as a much larger “field of play\". And while there are greater risks than on a
            ball field, most of what we fear is due to our old internal parent, that comes from a negative or judgmental
            place.

action_step:
What action can you take today that you have avoided, due to a negative perspective of your old internal
            parent? Switch into your Healthy Internal Parent we have been working on developing. Have that voice support
            you in taking this action.
journal_entry: Write about your effort to develop a healthier internal voice.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you address your fear and take a step forward yesterday? Appreciate being on The
            Path.
quote: "It is during our darkest moments that we must focus to see the light." Aristotle

step_of_the_day.title:
Finding The Path through turmoil and uncertainty. Look for the best way to be in the present moment (Pillars
            #4, 5, 6, 7, 8, & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
This year it feels like we go from bad to worse, only to see it get even worse. Between the natural
            disasters such as the Coronavirus, the resulting danger and constriction of life, the economic impact and
            hardship, the “natural\" man-made disasters of fires and flooding and the threat even to our democracy –
            life has been a roller coaster. When all this is going on there’s a natural tendency to shrink or withdraw
            from the world; to go into denial, depression, a sense of hopelessness, frustration or simply become
            anxious.While these reactions are understandable, they are also counterproductive. Reality doesn’t go away if you
            don’t look! Instead, all the issues remain, but then get layered with the emotional upset and resistance.
            And, you leave yourself less capable of coping.

action_step:
As I’ve been writing about, there is always a “best way\" of dealing with reality. If you accept this
            perspective, it will help you cope and have greater resilience, and ultimately – success! Here are the
            minimal steps:1. Accept this perspective and make the decision that you will focus on finding this “best way\". This
            decision – to take control – can be powerful and moves you away from a sense of helplessness or
            hopelessness.2. Allow yourself to notice, sit with, and express your feelings. Feelings that are not dealt with will have
            an unconscious and negative impact on you, as a part of you will always be distracted by trying to resolve
            this piece of unfinished business.3. Once you feel and express your feelings, shift your focus to actions, steps you can take – today – to
            move forward in your life.4. Look for the light. Don’t wait for it to find you.
journal_entry: Write about how you have been experiencing the crises of today.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Have you accepted the mindset that there is always a best way, a best path – The
            Path – even during today’s crises? If so, did you find it yesterday? Find and stay on The Path.
quote: "Only a life lived for others is a life worthwhile." Albert Einstein

step_of_the_day.title:
Getting and giving support to people you are closest with. Taking time to strengthen your relationships
            (Pillar #2)
step_of_the_day.content:
Part of your coping arsenal is in the power and support of your relationships. During this time of forced
            isolation, your connection with others is being tested. You don’t have the regular contacts that are part of
            the automatic nature of daily activities or many of the usual reasons for coming together, such as holidays,
            meetings, classes and other events. Instead it’s necessary to recognize the importance of these
            relationships and be proactive in connecting with them.Relationships are a source of support as well as what I refer to as “emotional nourishment\" that nurture
            your resilience.

action_step:
Make a list of the people in your life whom you love and care about. People you enjoy connecting with, who
            bring joy, pleasure, care and concern into your life. Even those acquaintances less frequently seen, but
            perhaps seen even less during this period. Reach out to a few each day. Hold the intention of sharing,
            caring and experiencing the warmth and support between the two of you going in both directions.
journal_entry: Write about how the pandemic has affected your relationships.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How well did you follow the steps last week to support your ability to cope and
            adapt? Give yourself credit for your successes while holding yourself accountable to improve – where you
            fell short. Remember why you are striving to be on The Path!
quote: “You will face many defeats in life, but never let yourself be defeated." Maya Angelou

step_of_the_day.title: Take a day for reflection. Today: review, feel, adjust and learn, make a plan, and let go (Pillars # 1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
I want to take a moment to appreciate all of you who have been following my daily steps and suggest that you
            appreciate yourselves as well. Remember, this is part of pillar #1, your relationship with yourself and
            giving yourself some love. It’s not bragging if you are honest and only saying it to yourself – it is
            self-love. Sticking with any new behavior is difficult, as the pull to the old pattern is like a magnet. So,
            again, appreciate yourselves for whatever resistance you had to deal with in following through. Last Monday was a day of meditation, reflection, atonement and adjustment, as I like to refer to Yom
            Kippur. While this is something that can be done more often, this day it’s more emphatic. Let’s take a day
            today to do some reflecting on your experience on and off The Path. You might even want to retake my
            Resilience Assessment Profile and note which areas you feel you’ve improved in and which you want to focus
            on.

action_step:
I have a few questions that – depending on your answer – determines how healthy and successful your life
            will be. One of these questions is suggested by Maya Angelou’s quote above. The decision that you will never
            be defeated – even when you might be experiencing a defeat – is a life changing decision! Can you either
            make this decision, or take a step closer to making it?Review your participation in The Path and the steps program. Are you meeting your goals? Note where you have
            – and also note, where you need to put more intention and energy.
journal_entry: Write about how you feel you are benefiting from participation in The Steps Program.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you walk on The Path yesterday by taking time to reflect and evaluate your
            progress? See you on The Path.

step_of_the_day.title: Find The Path today. Hold the intention to make this a day of optimal functioning (Pillars #1-9)
step_of_the_day.quote: You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough.
step_of_the_day.content: Today I’m challenging you to put what you have learned into practice. This means:

journal_entry: Write about any difficulty or resistance to today’s action steps.

review_and_appreciate: Review and Appreciate: Did you take steps to put yourself on The Path? The Path is always just a step away.

step_of_the_day.title:
A step toward simplification will help you be more effective and calmer. Focus on what’s in front of you and
            let go of everything else (Pillars #4 & 5)
step_of_the_day.quote: "Life is really simple, but we insist on making it complicated." Confucius
step_of_the_day.content:
Do you think you are good at “multi-tasking\"? Do you spend time thinking of all the tasks you need to do –
            right now? Do you pride yourself on the many balls you have in the air? These patterns develop over your
            lifetime and you get caught believing they are the way to be most productive, instead of just keeping you on
            the treadmill. First, multi-tasking is not multi-tasking. It is actually serially switching from one task to
            the next but trying to do them all at the same time. This is never the most efficient approach, as each
            switch from task to task requires extra time reorienting. But it sounds good. When I work with elite athletes to be peak performers, I emphasize a “calm-focused\" approach. Rather than
            a rushed, stressed, or tense, focused approach. Simplify:Simplify, in this context means, a) no matter how many tasks you have, you can only do one at time well, b)
            therefore when you choose your most important task to do, you set boundaries and only focus on that for the
            period of time you have allotted to it, c) that means not to shift any energy from the task you are on to
            worry about what is not getting done, and d) when doing any task, you will do it better if you come from a
            place of calmness.

action_step: Use the above approach as you tackle your day today and moving forward.
journal_entry: What old pattern keeps you on the treadmill?

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Were you able to simplify, tackle one task at a time, and then appreciate your
            success? Find The Path.
quote: "Whoever is happy will make others happy too." Anne Frank

step_of_the_day.title: Hold the intention and take responsibility to be happy sometime today (Pillars #1 & 6)
step_of_the_day.content:
The lessons we learn growing up are countless. Even how we ground ourselves emotionally is, to a great
            extent, learned. For example, we might learn how to be anxious by living with an anxious parent. This is
            also true of depression. Many who are depressed, simply never learned how to be happy. They didn’t
            experience enough of it growing up, as they learned to focus more on their depression. If you are focused on
            whether you are depressed, it will distract you from noticing when you are happy.

action_step:
Take responsibility today to find something to be happy about. If you have difficulty, try to identify
            what’s getting in your way. Usually it’s a message from your old and negative internal parent with some
            judgment or worry. If you notice this, try to shift, and come from the healthy voice we are working on
            developing. How does this support feeling happy?
journal_entry: Write about your relationship with happiness.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you find time and a way to be happy yesterday despite all the stresses? See you
            on The Path.
quote: “We are living in a weird time\" Heard spoken by many people

step_of_the_day.title:
Noticing your stresses but not letting them overwhelm you. Take the time you need to find a place of balance
            (Pillars #1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
“Weird\" covers a lot of territory. It refers to strange, stressful, difficult, out of the ordinary,
            overwhelming, fearful, and unpredictable – all that are being felt right now. You have been learning, on The
            Path, that ignoring or pushing down reality and your feelings only makes matters worse, since nothing goes
            away on its own. Dealing with your personal experience of weirdness, is to find the best way forward;
            realizing that there is always a best way.

action_step:
Allow yourself to feel whatever feelings you have about the current weirdness. Whether it’s anger,
            frustration, sadness, or loss, accept that this is your reality right now. By experiencing these feelings,
            you allow them to move through your body so you can then let them go more easily.Next, determine some action you can take to address your concerns. Identify steps that are doable. But
            remember, you can only do one step or action at a time.While you are doing one step, stay focused on it and realize that this puts you on The Path, so you can let
            go of what else needs to be done for the moment.Take time today to carve out 15 minutes of psychological space within which to say to yourself, “I’m safe\"
            - so you can let down your guard, and then practice a relaxation exercise for those 15 minutes.
journal_entry: Write about today’s steps on The Path.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How did you do yesterday in identifying and experiencing your feelings; and letting
            them go as you practiced a relaxation exercise. These simple steps put you on The Path.
quote: "Life is either a daring adventure or nothing at all." Helen Keller

step_of_the_day.title: Focusing on a “challenge\" rather than the problem (Pillars #5 & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
My fifth pillar of resilience is mental balance and mastery. This means recognizing that you have a choice
            in how you look at (perspective) and deal with (agency) each situation you experience in life. It means you
            consider what the best cognitive strategy is, rather than simply settling for the strategy you were taught
            and learned from your childhood environment.The optimal strategy includes:1. Viewing situations as challenges to be overcome, rather than problems to be fearful of or shrink
            from.2. Focusing on what needs to be done, rather than why it will be difficult or can’t be done, or what can get
            in the way. In other words, a positive approach.3. Coming from a place of, “Whatever it takes, I’ll reach inside to find the power and energy to get it
            done. I won’t give up.\" I’ll be persistent.4. What can I learn from this situation to support my personal growth and development and helping me be more
            effective for the next challenge? Committed to your personal development.

action_step: Follow the above 4 steps today.
journal_entry: Write about your old cognitive strategy and how it either supports you or gets in your way.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Your brain is capable of continually engaging in a developmental process. Or it can
            stay stuck in old patterns. If you followed yesterday’s steps, you are supporting its healthy development.
            It’s always possible to find The Path.
quote:
"Don't be distracted by criticism. Remember -- the only taste of success some people get is to take a bite
            out of you." Zig Ziglar

step_of_the_day.title:
Finding your resistance and what gets in your way of happiness. Noticing the negative messages that
            undermine your place of balance (Pillars #1, 5 & 6)
step_of_the_day.content:
While the quote above refers to the criticism of others, the most toxic criticism is what we give to
            ourselves. I’ve referred frequently to your Primitive Gestalt Pattern. This is the summation of all the
            lessons learned as you adapted to your childhood environment. These lessons learned – consciously and
            unconsciously, including when you were too young to even understand – guide your emotions, thinking and
            behavior. The spokesperson for this pattern is the internal voice – or what I refer to as your internal
            parent – that is with you 24/7. This voice, although we unconsciously believe and trust it, is not correct. The lessons it learned no
            longer serve or support you. In fact, whenever you are feeling bad, anxious or uncomfortable, it is usually
            because of a negative message from this place inside you. It has thrown you off-balance.

action_step:
Today, pay attention to how you undermine yourself with negative or self-critical messages. Label them as
            inappropriate and destructive. Then shift into the voice of a healthy internal parent coming from a place of
            love, compassion, support, acceptance and care. Start to listen and trust this new internal voice.
journal_entry: Write about your efforts to be good to yourself.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Appreciate your efforts for finding and being on The Path as we enter the 36th week
            of the “Steps\" program. Where you have fallen short, do not beat yourself up, but instead, hold the
            intention to keep working on the process. It’s always possible to find The Path.
quote:
"Successful people do what unsuccessful people are not willing to do. Don't wish it were easier; wish you
            were better." Jim Rohn

step_of_the_day.title:
Start the week by holding the intention to learn and grow in some way. Nothing remains the same. You either
            move forward or backward. Find your way to move forward today (Pillar #1)
step_of_the_day.content:
Your strength is in building a strong foundation. A strong foundation is built on trusting yourself.
            Trusting yourself is developed through doing what you say you are going to do and saying you are going to do
            what needs to be done. This process is built on holding yourself accountable from a place of love. The
            result is self-confidence.All the while, be careful that you are not being influenced by a negative internal voice

action_step: Identifying what needs to be done today and follow through, so that you can strengthen your foundation.
journal_entry: Write about this process of strengthening your foundation and trusting yourself and feeling self-confident.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you take steps yesterday to strengthen your foundation by following through with
            commitments? If so, that put you on The Path.

step_of_the_day.title:
Taking control of your thoughts to take control of your life. You have a choice as to where to place your
            attention. Choose the direction that moves you forward and doesn’t hold you back (Pillar #5)
step_of_the_day.content:
There is considerable research showing that your brain is influenced by your thoughts. In fact, in a recent
            study the researchers found that thinking positively actually sensitizes your brain to be more aware of
            what’s positive in your environment, while thinking negatively does the opposite – sensitizing your brain to
            be more negative.

action_step:
Use the message of this research to help your brain be more tuned in to what’s positive around you. Make the
            decision that you want to encourage a greater sensitivity to what’s positive, and thus, hold the intention
            to focus on the positive today. At the end of the day notice if this approach leaves you more satisfied.
journal_entry: Write about how you are influenced by expecting negative outcomes.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you focus more on the positive yesterday? If so, that put you on The Path. If
            not, it’s never too late to get back onto The Path.
quote: "Life is what happens when you're busy making other plans." John Lennon

step_of_the_day.title:
Be present as much as possible today. Presence is the key to performing at your best and it leads to your
            greatest growth (Pillar #7)
step_of_the_day.content:
Whether it’s busy making plans, or worrying, or regretting, it keeps you from being engaged in life, and
            present. Many people tell me that time and life are going by so quickly during this period of limited
            options. Without the events, the destinations, or vacations, it is easier to live on “automatic\" in which
            you go through the motions, or follow the pattern of yesterday – today, and tomorrow. With fewer markers of
            time, it appears to go by faster and faster.Another way of looking at this is to realize that under current conditions it’s more difficult to be
            present, to be awake in the moment. Yet, the only place from which to genuinely enjoy life, is in this very
            moment, and then every successive moment.I’ve been emphasizing the goal of “living by choice\"; choosing how to live, rather than simply following
            the old and conditioned pattern. To be able to make any choice, you first must realize that there is one,
            right in front of you. And that can only occur if you are awake in the moment. How can you “try\" to be more present? How can you develop the ability to be more present? What does it
            even mean to be present?Another way of thinking what being present means, is to be able to witness yourself in the moment. I once
            had a woman referred to me for PTSD who had been in a car accident. When I took her history, she indicated
            that she had been in five accidents in the past three years. The kicker was when she said, “And I wasn’t at
            fault in any of them\". But as she left the session, I noticed that she bumped into the furniture, and this
            explained it: she was not present. She wasn’t paying attention and thus didn’t notice the furniture in her
            way – just as she probably wasn’t paying sufficient attention or being present - when she was driving.

action_step:
Here are the steps to develop greater presence:1. Hold the intention to develop your ability to be present2. Create reminders throughout the day: cell phone alarm, post-its, or some environmental cue, such as each
            time you walk through a doorway. Use any of these cues to remind you to wake up.3. When you notice that you have not been present, say, for the last half hour or more, awaken to that
            moment with renewed intention.4. Be accepting of yourself and how you are doing. Remember this is a learning process.5. Repeat steps 1-4.
journal_entry: Write about the above process and how you are doing.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How much or how frequently were you able to experience being present yesterday? The
            Path is when you engage in the process of growth. Be on The Path.
quote: "Life is a succession of lessons which must be lived to be understood." Ralph Waldo Emerson

step_of_the_day.title:
The best way to learn to be present is to get a felt sense of the experience. Noticing what being present
            feels like (Pillar #7)
step_of_the_day.content: All the words on this page, in this book, cannot substitute for your experience. You cannot learn about being present, for example, from reading—only from holding the intension to be present. Eugene Gendlin introduced the concept of a “felt sense” as a way to feel into your inner experience. By doing so, you offer yourself an opportunity to uncover parts of you that have been hidden by your defenses and by simply being busy. It is also a way to connect your mind with your body and fully experience being present. Mr. Emerson, in his quote, says, if you want to really learn a lesson and understand it, it must be lived.

action_step:
As RWE says, if you want to really learn a lesson and understand it, it must be lived. Therefore, today it’s
            about being present, but then, most importantly, pay attention to how you feel and experience being present.
            This is The Path to getting it.
journal_entry: Write about your experience with presence.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you “feel into\" your experience of being present at any time yesterday? Take
            The Path.
quote: "Life is trying things to see if they work." Ray Bradbury

step_of_the_day.title:
Give yourself the opportunity to experiment today. Find a way to move outside your boundaries (Pillar #8
            & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
We take life so seriously. And of course, there is good reason to; especially these days. But “serious\"
            locks us into rigidness and a reluctance to step into new territory and growth. Resilience involves the
            ability to be flexible, open to new approaches and finding your rhythm.

action_step:
Give yourself the opportunity to move outside your boundaries today. Take a step, an action, that is new or
            different for you. From the place of your healthy internal parent, give yourself permission to try this new
            behavior or approach, and let it be ok that it might not work out. But any new step you take will be, at the
            very least, a learning experience. This will support your healthy growth.
journal_entry: Write about your willingness to try something new.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Were you resourceful yesterday? Did you make time to experiment and try something
            new? See you on The Path.
quote: "The secret of success is to do the common thing uncommonly well." John D. Rockefeller Jr.

step_of_the_day.title: Understanding your “Resilience Response\" score (Pillars #1-9)
step_of_the_day.content:
Many years ago, Herbert Benson popularized the notion of a “relaxation response\". This was essentially
            about going into a parasympathetic or recovery mode that is experienced as a sense of relaxation. A typical
            relaxation or visualization exercise helps a person engage in this response.Today I’m introducing the concept of a “Resilience Response\" which focuses on the fact that there is always
            an optimal response – moment by moment – in your life that results in or maintains your greatest resilience.
            This response occurs when you are able to be present and aware, without the baggage of negative or
            judgmental thoughts, fear, or unconscious emotional unfinished business. This response balances the numerous
            variables that go into being present and being in a place of harmony, while making the best choices to
            maximize getting your needs met. This Resilience Response score begins with your assessment along my nine
            pillars of resilience and success.

action_step:
Review what the nine pillars of resilience and success are and give yourself a total score of Resilience,
            based on how you feel you are developing along the nine dimensions.
journal_entry: Write about your subjective assessment of your resilience.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Appreciate your decision to find and be on The Path as we enter the 37th week of the
            “Steps\" program. Where you have fallen short, do not beat yourself up, but instead, hold the intention to
            do better. It’s always possible to find The Path.
quote: "If you want to achieve excellence, you can get there today. As of this second, quit doing less-than-excellent work." Thomas J. Watson

step_of_the_day.title:
Support your integrity by having your inner and out self be on the same page. Hold yourself accountable to
            the level you aspire to (Pillars #1 & 9)
step_of_the_day.content:
You have a “public self\". That’s the image you portray to the world. It’s your best effort to be accepted
            and successful. It’s your best imitation of what you think others are most likely to approve. Too often,
            however, this includes hiding the self – or aspects of yourself - you are ashamed of or afraid will be
            negatively judged by others. Integrity, that maintains resilience, is to have inner and outer selves match.
            This is within your reach.The two keys to integrity:1. Aspire to be the person you want to be and want people to see.2.When you reach for this level of excellence, accept, and appreciate yourself.

action_step:
Today, as Mr. Wilson suggests: if you want to achieve integrity, as of this second, quit doing less than the
            level of work that you aspire to, while being the person you want others to see. If you want to achieve
            excellence, as of this second, quit doing less-than-excellent work. Make this your credo for today.
journal_entry: Write about the level that you aspire to. Is it a level of excellence? If not, what level is it?

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you hold yourself accountable yesterday? Did you decide if you were aiming for
            excellence? If not, then what level would you be okay with and have integrity – inner and outer harmony?
            Find The Path.
quote: "Before anything else, preparation is the key to success." Alexander Graham Bell

step_of_the_day.title:
What can you do today to prepare to be on The Path? If you are having difficulty being or staying on The
            Path, let’s take today to “prepare\" to be on The Path.
step_of_the_day.content:
Some of you may be finding it difficult to follow the “Steps\" sent to you each day. Perhaps you have lost
            interest, or simply don’t have time to pay attention. There is the story of the two lumberjacks. The first
            worked so hard every day. Working non-stop from 8 in the morning to 6 at night. For his efforts there was a
            big stack of cut wood. The second lumberjack also started chopping at 8 in the morning. But every hour he
            took a break. He too finished at 6 in the evening. Next to him was an even larger pill of wood, almost
            double that of the first.Every hour, when he took a break, he sharpened his ax.

action_step: Today think about what it takes to prepare to be on The Path:1. Deciding that you want to become the best you can be.2. Deciding you want to be healthier and slow the aging process.3. Making the decision that you want to take the time to develop greater resilience.4. Making the decision to commit to being on The Path.
journal_entry: Write about your resistance to taking steps every day.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Yesterday’s action steps were designed to reinforce your commitment to healthy
            goals. Did you take them? Committing to The Path, ensures greater success.
quote: "The real test is not whether you avoid this failure, because you won't. It's whether you let it harden or shame you into inaction, or whether you learn from it; whether you choose to persevere." Barack Obama

step_of_the_day.title: Overcoming a defeat, failure or loss. How to recover after messing up.
step_of_the_day.content:
As former president Obama says, you won’t go through life avoiding failure. Life is complicated. Achieving
            success has its twists and turns. Mistakes are part of the process. In fact, it’s part of any learning
            process. The rocket ship that took our astronauts to the moon was off course 98% of the time, but it was
            continually receiving feedback and making adjustments that kept bringing it back on course. Similarly,
            mistakes give you feedback to help you get it right, the next time. It’s important not to be shamed or
            discouraged in this natural process

action_step:
Identify a mistake or failure that you haven’t let go of. It might have come during an interaction with
            someone, perhaps in a business or school situation. It might be a business failure or mistake that cost you
            a lot. Here are the steps for letting go:1. Experience and express whatever feelings are attached to this experience; sadness, loss, anger or
            frustration.2. Find the lesson to be learned. If there was a loss from the mistake – a cost – you want to balance this
            out with a benefit – a lesson.3. Hold the intention not to be defeated, but to rebound stronger.4. Forgive yourself and let go.
journal_entry: Write about your resistance to taking steps every day.

review_and_appreciate: Review and Appreciate: Did you let go of a mistake you have been holding on to? See you on The Path.
quote:
“We are social beings who experience emotional nourishment through our relationships\" Stephen Sideroff,
            PhD

step_of_the_day.title:
A focus on social bonding to enhance resilience. Take time to strengthen positive relationships and
            experience emotional nourishment (Pillar #2)
step_of_the_day.content:
Emotional nourishment occurs when we experience positive regard in our relationships. It is in these
            experiences that our bodies release oxytocin, as well as neurotransmitters such as dopamine. These
            biochemicals, in turn, help us feel calmer and enhance our ability to deal with stress. New research is also
            suggesting that higher levels of oxytocin increase feelings of joy and security.It’s easy to fall into patterns of isolation during the pandemic. Staying in contact, creating opportunities
            for warm relationships requires greater intention. Yet, it’s these very relationships that help you cope
            with the challenges of today’s world.

action_step:
Today contact people in your life with whom you feel positive emotions. In each case, take the time to share
            feelings. During these encounters allow yourself to appreciate the support and care you are receiving and
            make sure you return these same feelings.
journal_entry: Write about how good it feels to connect with people you love.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you take time to connect with intimate friends or family? Was it emotionally
            nourishing? Find The Path to better cope with today’s crises.
quote: "I alone cannot change the world, but I can cast a stone across the water to create many ripples." Mother Teresa

step_of_the_day.title:
Holding the purpose of contributing to your community. Finding ways to contribute to your community (Pillar
            #3)
step_of_the_day.content:
A resilient community supports individual resilience. A resilient community is one in which there is a
            feeling of safety and connection. These qualities of harmony have a direct effect on the nervous system of
            the individuals who live in that society. A person who is resilient will hold the intention to contribute to
            making his or her community more resilient.

action_step:
Identify some action you can engage in to help make your community more resilient. Right now, all our
            communities are in the midst of elections. This is one area you may want to volunteer to support this
            process.
journal_entry: Write about how the peacefulness or conflict of your community affects you.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you give community service yesterday to develop your pillar #3 of resilience?
            Stay on The Path.
quote: “If you really look closely, most overnight successes took a long time.\" Steve Jobs

step_of_the_day.title: Strengthen your persistence muscle today. Reaching deeper inside to grow your self-confidence (Pillar #9)
step_of_the_day.content:
There are certain qualities that support your resilience and success. Qualities that help you face the
            challenges of today. What’s most important to realize is that you are not born with these qualities – you
            develop them by following through with difficult actions. At the top of the list is persistence, which is
            related to your “will\". It’s your effort – and ultimately your ability - to keep going no matter how
            daunting the situation. It comes from tackling difficult tasks and holding the intention to continue despite
            the obstacles. The more you take this approach and follow through, the better you will get at it. The results include
            greater trust in yourself and greater self-confidence.

action_step:
Identify some action you can engage in to help make your community more resilient. Right now, all our
            communities are in the midst of elections. This is one area you may want to volunteer to support this
            process.
journal_entry: Write about how the peacefulness or conflict of your community affects you.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: The notion of “The Path\" and the “steps\" is to support your growing ability to
            handle stress, be resilient and successful. It is the recognition that all these goals are achieved through
            a developmental process. A step by step process. Did you take the step, yesterday, of developing your
            ability to be persistent? That put you on The Path.
quote:
“I was shocked when I came to the West to see so much self-hatred, instead of self-compassion\" The Dalai
            Lama

step_of_the_day.title: Strengthening your inner voice’s focus on loving yourself and self-compassion (Pillar #1)
step_of_the_day.content:
How you treat yourself is at the heart of your ability to be and stay in balance. And this determines how
            resilient and successful you will be. The Dalai Lama’s observation is both accurate and sad, that we tend to
            treat ourselves more negatively.Self-compassion is like an emotional “balm\" that soothes our wounds and our mistakes. It thus helps us
            recover from the slings and arrows of life. Those who think that being hard on themselves results in better
            performance are operating under a painful illusion that has the opposite result, leaving us feeling less
            worthy and beaten down.

action_step:
Identify some of your mistakes, emotional wounding, or losses. As you reflect on them, hear your developing
            healthy internal parent – coming from a place of love – show you, and express to you compassion. If you find
            this difficult to do, think about how you respond to a close friend or relative who experiences a loss and
            how caring you are with them. Turn that expression back onto yourself.image.png
journal_entry: Write about how you are doing with the development of your healthy internal voice.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you take time to love and have compassion for yourself? Was it easy or
            difficult? Enjoy The Path.
quote: “Life has its rhythm, and your dance with life also has its rhythm\" Stephen Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title:
Rhythm and resilience: sensing your optimal rhythm and flow of energy that enhances your resilience and
            allows you to be in synchrony with your needs and your actions (Pillar #4)
step_of_the_day.content:
I’ve said in other places that our supply of energy is finite. There is plenty there, but it can be easily
            wasted or sent in non-productive – and even destructive - directions. This occurs, for example, when you
            hold on to emotions such as anger and resentment or engage in unnecessary worrying. This leaves you less
            resilient. The most basic of personal goals is to be efficient and effective with your energy – using it
            purposefully – and then making sure you engage in a recovery process. Remember, everything you do and
            everything your body does to stay healthy, requires energy. There are different ways of tuning in to your body and how efficient you are being with your energy. You
            can take your pulse, or heartbeat, for example. The Chinese have 29 different locations for taking the pulse
            and derive different meanings from each combination. You can use your hand as a sensor, placed on your
            chest. If you do this consistently you will begin to notice differences in vibrational tone. With practice
            this can inform you of your “mind-body\" state. For example, you might check in and discover excess
            vibration that indicates an over-activation of your body. When you do this, your body is telling you it
            needs some calming. If you then address this, you are getting into harmony with your body.

action_step:
Bring the fingers of your right hand to your left wrist and feel your pulse. If you slide your fingers down
            from your thumb to your wrist you will find your pulse. Take a moment to “tune in\" to the beat of your
            heart that is represented by this pulse. There is an important relationship between your nervous system,
            your cardiovascular system, your respiratory system and even your emotional system.
journal_entry: What do you notice about your own rhythm?

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Were you able to sit for five minutes, and follow your pulse as you breathed in and
            breathed out? Did you notice how your breath affected your pulse? Being on The Path puts you in rhythm with
            your body and your life.
quote: “Acceptance – accepting reality – leads to harmony and being in rhythm with life\" - Stephen Sideroff

step_of_the_day.title:
Being in acceptance with your body sensations, emotions and your rhythm. Acceptance, being present, letting
            go and restoring balance (Pillars #4 & 7)
step_of_the_day.content:
So many of your problems begin with an effort to deny or not notice aspects of reality that you don’t like
            or feel uncomfortable with, such as unpleasant emotions or body sensations. Your effort to deny has two
            negative consequences: 1) it establishes a pattern of unconsciousness and avoidance, and 2) it makes it
            impossible to recognize unmet needs; a necessary step in getting these needs met. The result is less
            effective functioning, self-deprivation, and more stress than is necessary as your lack of awareness takes
            you in the wrong direction. When you are willing to accept the reality of your emotions, tension in your body, and other real
            discomforts, this puts you on The Path of balance and resilience. Awareness of unmet needs is necessary to
            get these needs met. Don’t hide from the truths your body is showing you.

action_step:
Just as you did yesterday, place the fingers of your left hand on your right wrist and feel your pulse.
            Begin breathing at approximately six breaths per second, or four seconds in and six seconds out. Tune in to
            your pulse and see if you can notice it increasing as you breathe in and decreasing as you breath out. At
            the same time notice any tension in your body. Also, notice feelings or unfinished business that begins to
            show up in your body and thoughts. Simply allow all that is happening, without judgment. Do you notice,
            emerging, any unmet needs?
journal_entry: What unfinished business or uncomfortable sensations did you notice during this exercise?Awareness within the context of acceptance is the first step in getting your needs met.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: As you practiced your restorative breathing, did any unfinished emotional business
            come to the surface? Find The Path.
quote: “The past hijacks our present\" Fritz Perls (co-founder of Gestalt Therapy)

step_of_the_day.title: Finishing your unfinished emotional business is an inside job (Pillar #6)
step_of_the_day.content:
How does the past hijack our present, as Perls had said? It is an organismic goal to notice what’s left
            unresolved – such as unexpressed emotions - and then find a way to get resolution. When this doesn’t happen,
            there is a pull toward resolution, be it conscious or unconscious. In other words, a part of us is
            distracted by this need. But in addition, our efforts to not notice emotional unfinished business
            contributes to anxiety, depression and scotomas, or blind spots in our awareness. When that unfinished
            emotional business is the need for acceptance or love, it will get channeled in non-productive directions.
            For example, striving for more money, or working harder, which will never fill an emotional hole. And
            finally, as unexpressed or unnoticed emotions build up (because they don’t go away by themselves) they
            provide a pool of energy that can get touched into by small events, triggering big reactions. Some feel stuck holding on to emotions because they are either uncomfortable with the feelings or fear the
            consequences of their expression to someone who, well, just might get upset as well. If you recognize that
            what’s unfinished is the expression of the emotion, not that the other person hears you or acknowledges your
            feelings in any way, it opens an avenue for the expression and release of those emotions

action_step:
Here are the steps to take to let go of unfinished emotional business.1. Identify a feeling that you have been holding on to with another person.2. Decide that you would like to let go of this feeling rather than holding on to a resentment.3. Recognize that this isn’t about changing someone else, which is impossible to do. Accept this fact.4. Find a way to express your feelings: write a letter that you can tear up, yell at the person, beat a
            pillow or other soft object, or even a body bag. The more you can let it out, the more likely you will be
            able to let go.5. Decide that the only person who suffers by holding on to the feeling is you; and then let go.
journal_entry: Write about your style of dealing with your emotions.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: How successful were you in addressing some unfinished emotional business? These
            efforts will result in your growing ability to be present. This puts you on The Path.
quote:
“Be yourself, express yourself freely and without fear. After all, those who truly love you won’t mind what
            you say or do\" Fritz Perls

step_of_the_day.title: How comfortable are you to be yourself? Strive today to let more of who you are, come out (Pillar #1)
step_of_the_day.content:
The perceived judgments of others frequently get in the way of you simply being yourself. It might cause you
            hesitation when you are about to speak. It might stop you from getting up to dance at a wedding, or other
            event. Your own judgments might even stop you from doing something when you are by yourself. Remember, all
            these concerns originate in your old internal voice/parent. If you turn, instead, to your healthy internal
            parent, he or she will be coming from a place of love, acceptance and support. He or she will say, “be
            yourself, you are ok.\"

action_step:
Today, try to listen to your healthy internal voice. From that place say or do something that might be a bit
            uncomfortable but is an expression of you.
journal_entry: Write about aspects of yourself that you hide from others.

review_and_appreciate:
Review and Appreciate: Did you find some true expression of yourself yesterday. How did it feel? Find The
            Path today.
quote: "A successful man is one who can lay a firm foundation with the bricks others have thrown at him." David Brinkley

step_of_the_day.title:
Letting go of negativity and supporting your foundation. Overcoming criticism from others, or yourself
            (Pillars #1 & 2)
step_of_the_day.content:
It is easy to be impacted by criticism, real or imagined. It can hurt. It can stop you in your tracks. It
            can intimidate you. But most importantly, it can undermine and get in the way of reaching your goals. Part
            of the impact of judgements is how they touch into your own insecurities and your own self-judgement. It’s
            important not to be a victim of others or your own negative comments.

action_step:
To combat the fear of negative judgements, it’s important to find and establish a healthy place to ground
            yourself. I’m referring to an internal center that is loving and accepting, or what I’ve been referring to
            as your “Healthy Internal Parent\" (HIP). No one is perfect and we all make mistakes. When you anchor
            yourself to a healthy internal voice, reminding you that you are “OK\", that is accepting of you and
            compassionate, you can overcome the negativity. But first you must remember to decide that it doesn’t
            support you to listen to or believe the criticism. So, today, when you hear or imagine judgements from
            others or hear it from your own inner voice, make sure to label it as inappropriate and destructive. Then
            shift into the healthy voice where you are now anchoring yourself, and give yourself these positive
            messages. Remember “neurons that fire together, wire together.\"
